facts.text: Writ Petition No. 205 of 1971 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 205 of 1971. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: District Magistrate, 24 Parganas passed detention order on March 2, 1971 under section 3(1) read with 3(3) of West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: This petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenges the validity of the order dated March 2, 1971 passed by the District Magistrate, 24 Pargana, in exercise of the powers companyferred on him under sub-section  1  read with sub-section  3  of S. 3 of the West Bengal  Prevention of Violent Activities  Act, 1970 Act No. XIX of 1970  hereinafter to be referred as the Act , directing the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: District Magistrate satisfied that detention necessary to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to security of State or maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned order states that the District Magistrate was satisfied that it was necessary that the petitioner should be detained with a view to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order as provided by S. 3 1  of the Act.

facts.text: District Magistrate reported detention to State Government on March 3, 1971 with grounds and particulars.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit in reply of the District Magistrate, he reported under S. 3  4  of the Act to the State Government On March 3, 1971 regarding the fact of his having passed the order of detention together with the grounds of detention and all other. particulars having a bearing on the name.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on March 5, 1971 and served with detention order and grounds same day.

anchor.surface_text: It is further stated that the. petitioner was arrested on March 5, 1971 and was served on the- same day with the order of detention together with the, grounds for passing the order of detention.

facts.text: Petitioner informed of right to make representation to State Government via Assistant Secretary, Home (Special) Department.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was also informed that he is entitled to make a representation to the State Government against the order of detention and that such representation is to be addressed to the Assistant Secretary Home  Special  DEpartment, Government of West Bengal and forwarded through the Superintendent of Jail.

facts.text: Petitioner informed case would be placed before Advisory Board within 30 days under section 10.

anchor.surface_text: He was further informed that his case will be placed under s. 10 of the Act before, the Advisory Board within 30 days from the date of the order of detention.

facts.text: State Government approved detention order on March 11, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companysidered the report of the District Magistrate together with other materials placed before it and approved, on March 11, 1971 as required by S. 3  4  of the Act, the order of detention passed by the District Magistrate.

facts.text: State Government sent report to Central Government on March 11, 1971 under section 3(5).

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, as required,by S. 3 5  the State Government sent the necessary report to the Central Government.

facts.text: Petitioner's case placed before Advisory Board on April 3, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government on April 3, 1971 placed the case of the petitioner before the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Petitioner sent representations dated March 17, 1971 and April 19, 1971 denying allegations and admitting arrest on March 5, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner sent two representations dated March 17, and April 19, 1971 denying the allegations made in the grounds for passing the order of detention and pleaded that he was innocent. He has admitted in these representations that he was arrested on March 5, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner did not request personal hearing before Advisory Board in representations.

anchor.surface_text: In neither of these representations did the petitioner make a request that he should be provided an opportunity of being heard in person by the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Advisory Board submitted report on May 11, 1971 finding sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: The Advisory Board after companysidering the, materials placed before it relating to the detention of the petitioner including the represen- tations made by him on March 17, 1971 and April 19, 1971, submitted its report on May 11, 1971 to the State Government stating that it is of opinion that there is sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention on July 12, 1971 under section 12(1) for twelve months from date of detention.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government passed an order on July 12, 1971 under S. 12 1  of the Act companyfirming the order of detention dated March 2, 1971 passed by the District Magistrate and directed that the petitioners detention shall be companytinued till the expiration of twelve months from the date of his detention.

facts.text: On 26-1-71 between 11.00 and 12.31 hours, petitioner and associates armed with bombs etc. at Piali Railway Station terrorized passengers on trains SC 193 UP and SC 195 UP.

anchor.surface_text: That, on 26-1-71 between 11.00 and 12.31 hours, you along with your associates being armed with bombs, ballasts, pipe guns, lathis etc., assembled at Piali Railway Station and created terror among the passengers by charging bombs and showering ballasts indiscriminately and also moving from companypartment to companypartment of train Nos. SC 193 UP and SC 195 UP in search of your rivals, shouting that if I get the Rascal, I will kill them and in doing so you caused injury to some innocent passengers and broke the glass panes of drivers cab of SC 195 Up. You created disturbance of the public order thereby.

facts.text: On 2-2-71 at about 17.39 hours, petitioner and associates armed with bombs, daggers etc. attacked guard of train SC 199 UP at Champahati Railway Station.

anchor.surface_text: That, on 2-2-71 at about 17.39 hours, you along with your associates, being armed with bombs, daggers etc., attacked and assaulted the guard of train No. SC 199 Up at Champahati Railway Station and also created terror among the passengers by charging a bomb. You created disturbance of the public order thereby.

facts.text: On 9-2-71 at about 13.15 hours, petitioner and associates charged bombs and ballasts on police at Jadavpur Railway Station seizing rice from SC 195 UP.

anchor.surface_text: That on 9-2-71 at about 13.15 hours you and your associates charged bombs and ballasts on duty Police party at Jadavpur Railway Station as they seized 10 bags of rice weighing about 3 quintals from SC 195 Up, while you were taking the said stock to Calcutta rationing area illegally by train. Your attack grew so violent that the Police party had to open fire upon you in self- defence. Your violent activities created serious panic in the Station area and the public order was disturbed thereby.

facts.text: Petitioner denied involvement in violent activities in representations and claimed to be innocent mason.

anchor.surface_text: In the two representations-dated March 17 and April 19, 1971 made to the State Government, the petitioner after referring to the fact that he was arrested on March 5, 1971 has denied that he was involved in any of the types of violent activities referred to in the grounds for detention. He has further stated that he is leading a very honest life doing the work of mason and that the allegations made against him are false.

facts.text: District Magistrate stated petitioner is rice smuggler operating in suburban railway trains attacking with bombs.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate has stated that the petitioner is rice smuggler operating in Subarban Railway trains in Southern Section of Eastern Railway and that he along with his associates armed with bombs and other deadly weapons attacked the passengers and the guard of railway trains and created terror by hurling bombs in Champahati and Piali Railway Stations.

facts.text: Court satisfied that detention order validly passed based on District Magistrate's averments not controverted.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied from the averments made by the District Magistrate in the companynter-affidavit, which have number been further companytroverted by the petitioner by filing any rejoinder that the order of detention has been validly and properly passed.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit paragraph 6 erroneously stated Advisory Board heard petitioner in person.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that in paragraph 6 of the companynter affidavit it has been mentioned that the Advisory Board submitted its report on May 11, 1971 after hearing the petitioner. This statement is obviously wrong because the petitioner never asked for being heard in person.

facts.text: Petitioner did not allege mala fides or challenge jurisdiction in writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: It Will be numbered from his averments in the writ petition that except denying that the allegations are false and that he has never participated in any of those incidents referred to in the grounds of detention, he has number alleged any mala fides number challenged the jurisdiction of the officer who, passed the order of detention or the various proceedings companynected therewith.

facts.text: State Government rejected petitioner's representations but forwarded to Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government rejected the representations of the petitioner, but forwarded them to the Advisory Board for being companysidered.

facts.text: Petitioner challenged detention claiming no offences committed and allegations false.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has challenged the order of detention on the ground that he has never companymitted any offence number has he been involved in any illegal activities as alleged in the grounds of detention. He has further stated that the various allegations mentioned against him are false and that he never participated in any of the incidents referred to in the grounds of detention.

facts.text: District Magistrate passed order on own satisfaction after considering materials.

anchor.surface_text: It is further stated that the deponent after receiving reliable information relating to the anti-social and prejudicial activities of the petitioner and after carefully companysidering these materials, he was fully satisfied that the petitioner was engaged and was indulging in activities which were prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order, and that his detention was essential.

issues.text: Whether the order of detention is illegal because the grounds furnished only refer to disturbance of public order while the order mentions acting prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order, without specific grounds for security of the State, and whether this indicates consideration of extraneous matters or ambiguity in the basis of detention

anchor.surface_text: Mr. V. Mayakrishnan, Amicus Curiae, appearing on behalf of the petitioner has urged that every one of the grounds has referred to the activities of the petitioner having resulted in disturbance of public order. But the order of detention refers to the fact that the District Magistrate was of the view that the petitioner should be detained with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order. No ground showing as to how any activity of the petitioner is prejudicial to the security of the State justifying the order Of detention has been furnished to the petitioner. Therefore, according to the learned counsel, the order of detention is illegal inasmuch as the petitioner has not been informed of any grounds as to how his activities are prejudicial to the security of the State.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention are vague or lack sufficient particulars to enable the petitioner to make effective representation

Whether the activities alleged in the grounds of detention fall within the definition of 'acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order' under section 3(2) of the Act, particularly clause (d) involving offences under the Explosive Substances Act
Whether the erroneous statement in the counter-affidavit that the Advisory Board heard the petitioner in person vitiates the detention proceedings

issues.text: Whether all procedural requirements under sections 3(4), 3(5), 10, 11 and 12(1) of the Act were complied with

arguments.claim: Order of detention illegal as grounds refer only to public order disturbance but order includes security of State without specific grounds, indicating extraneous matters and ambiguity.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. V. Mayakrishnan, Amicus Curiae, appearing on behalf of the petitioner has urged that every one of the grounds has referred to the activities of the petitioner having resulted in disturbance of public order. But the order of detention refers to the fact that the District Magistrate was of the view that the petitioner should be detained with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 3(2) definition applies clauses (a)-(e) to both security of State and public order; no need for separate grounds.

arguments.claim: Activities in grounds fall within section 3(2), particularly clause (d) as offences under Explosive Substances Act, 1908, prejudicial to security of State or public order.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. P. Mitra, learned counsel appearing for the State drew our attention to the provisions contained in s. 3 2 of the Act and pointed out that the various acts mentioned in the grounds of detention come within the expressions acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order. In particular he relied upon cl. d of s. 2

arguments.court_reasoning: Clauses (a)-(e) of s.3(2) cover both; petitioner's bomb-charging activities under Explosive Substances Act s.3 and cl.(d).

arguments.claim: District Magistrate satisfied detention necessary based on reliable information and materials; petitioner engaged in prejudicial activities as rice smuggler using bombs, terrorizing public.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate has stated that the petitioner is rice smuggler operating in Subarban Railway trains in Southern Section of Eastern Railway and that he along with his associates armed with bombs and other deadly weapons attacked the passengers and the guard of railway trains and created terror by hurling bombs in Champahati and Piali Railway Stations.

arguments.claim: Section 3(2) provides dictionary meaning; clauses (a)-(e) apply to both security of State and maintenance of public order; grounds valid as activities fall under cl.(d) and Explosive Substances Act s.3.
Grounds of detention contain sufficient particulars (dates, places, times, trains); not vague despite no names of associates.
Erroneous statement in counter-affidavit para 6 that Advisory Board heard petitioner in person does not vitiate proceedings as petitioner never requested hearing.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that in paragraph 6 of the counter affidavit it has been mentioned that the Advisory Board submitted its report on May 11, 1971 after hearing the petitioner. This statement is obviously wrong because the petitioner never asked for being heard in person.

arguments.claim: All procedural requirements under ss.3(1),(3),(4),(5),10,11,12(1) complied with; representations considered; no personal hearing requested.

anchor.surface_text: order dated March 2, 1971 passed by the District Magistrate... reported under S. 3 4 ... approved on March 11... sent report to Central Government... placed before Advisory Board April 3... confirmed July 12 under S.12(1)

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts show compliance; petitioner did not challenge procedures or allege mala fides.

arguments.claim: Petitioner did not allege mala fides or challenge jurisdiction or proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It Will be seen from his averments in the writ petition that except denying that the allegations are false and that he has never participated in any of those incidents referred to in the grounds of detention, he has not alleged any mala fides nor challenged the jurisdiction of the officer who, passed the order of detention or the various proceedings connected therewith.

holdings.text: The order of detention has been validly and properly passed.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied from the averments made by the District Magistrate in the counter-affidavit, which have not been further controverted by the petitioner by filing any rejoinder that the order of detention has been validly and properly passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Averments in District Magistrate's counter-affidavit accepted as uncontroverted by rejoinder; all procedural steps under ss.3(1),(3),(4),(5),10,11,12(1) complied with as per record.

holdings.text: The erroneous statement in the counter-affidavit that the Advisory Board heard the petitioner in person does not vitiate the detention.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that in paragraph 6 of the counter affidavit it has been mentioned that the Advisory Board submitted its report on May 11, 1971 after hearing the petitioner. This statement is obviously wrong because the petitioner never asked for being heard in person. [...] But that does not in any manner advance the case of the petitioner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner never requested personal hearing under s.11; mistake is inadvertent and regretted by State counsel; no prejudice caused.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention cannot be held to be vague nor can the order of detention be held to be invalid on the ground that extraneous or irrelevant matters were considered or that there is ambiguity between security of State and public order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.3(2) clauses (a)-(e) apply to both 'security of State' and 'maintenance of public order'; no separate grounds needed for security; textual reading of statute.

holdings.text: The petitioner's activities fall within the definition under s.3(2), particularly cl.(d), as committing offences under the Explosive Substances Act, 1908, prejudicial to security of State or public order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bomb-charging and explosions in incidents match s.3 Explosive Substances Act; directly covered by cl.(d) of s.3(2) WBPVA which deems such acts prejudicial to both security and public order.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention contain sufficient particulars and are not vague.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dates, places, times, train numbers, and petitioner's association specified; omission of associates' names does not render vague as essentials provided for effective representation.

holdings.text: For all the above reasons, the order of detention is valid.

anchor.surface_text: For all the above reasons, we are satisfied that the order of detention is valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of valid subjective satisfaction, compliance with procedures, adequate grounds, and activities fitting statutory definition under s.3.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied from the averments made by the District Magistrate in the counter-affidavit, which have not been further controverted by the petitioner by filing any rejoinder that the order of detention has been validly and properly passed.
For all the above reasons, we are satisfied that the order of detention is valid.

It may be pointed out that in paragraph 6 of the counter affidavit it has been mentioned that the Advisory Board submitted its report on May 11, 1971 after hearing the petitioner. This statement is obviously wrong because the petitioner never asked for being heard in person. [...] But that does not in any manner advance the case of the petitioner
For all the above reasons, we are satisfied that the order of detention is valid.
